lines.text: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with thee.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: I am so; I do love it better than laughing.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Why then, 'tis good to be a post.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is emulation, nor the musician's, which is fantastical, nor the courtier's, which is proud, nor the soldier's, which is ambitious, nor the lawyer's, which is politic, nor the lady's, which is nice, nor the lover's, which is all these: but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry's contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me m a most humorous sadness.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason to be sad: I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men's; then, to have seen much and to have nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Yes, I have gained my experience.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And your experience makes you sad: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad; and to travel for it too!
Enter ORLANDO

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind!

lines.speaker: jaques
lines.text: Nay, then, God be wi' you, an you talk in blank verse.
Exit

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Farewell, Monsieur Traveller: look you lisp and wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of your own country, be out of love with your nativity and almost chide God for making you that countenance you are, or I will scarce think you have swam in a gondola. Why, how now, Orlando! where have you been all this while? You a lover! An you serve me such another trick, never come in my sight more.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Break an hour's promise in love! He that will divide a minute into a thousand parts and break but a part of the thousandth part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said of him that Cupid hath clapped him o' the shoulder, but I'll warrant him heart-whole.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight: I had as lief be wooed of a snail.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Of a snail?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he carries his house on his head; a better jointure, I think, than you make a woman: besides he brings his destiny with him.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for: but he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And I am your Rosalind.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a Rosalind of a better leer than you.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday humour and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, an I were your very very Rosalind?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I would kiss before I spoke.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were gravelled for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss. Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking--God warn us!--matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: How if the kiss be denied?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: What, of my suit?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit. Am not I your Rosalind?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I take some joy to say you are, because I would be talking of her.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Well in her person I say I will not have you.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Then in mine own person I die.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicit, in a love-cause. Troilus had his brains dashed out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love. Leander, he would have lived many a fair year, though Hero had turned nun, if it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont and being taken with the cramp was drowned and the foolish coroners of that age found it was 'Hero of Sestos.' But these are all lies: men have died from time to time and worms have eaten them, but not for love.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind, for, I protest, her frown might kill me.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition, and ask me what you will. I will grant it.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Then love me, Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: And wilt thou have me?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, and twenty such.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: What sayest thou?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Are you not good?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I hope so.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing? Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us. Give me your hand, Orlando. What do you say, sister?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Pray thee, marry us.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: I cannot say the words.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: You must begin, 'Will you, Orlando--'

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I will.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, but when?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Why now; as fast as she can marry us.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Then you must say 'I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.'

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I might ask you for your commission; but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband: there's a girl goes before the priest; and certainly a woman's thought runs before her actions.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: So do all thoughts; they are winged.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: For ever and a day.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Say 'a day,' without the 'ever.' No, no, Orlando; men are April when they woo, December when they wed: maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey: I will weep for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and that when thou art inclined to sleep.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: But will my Rosalind do so?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: By my life, she will do as I do.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: O, but she is wise.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Or else she could not have the wit to do this: the wiser, the waywarder: make the doors upon a woman's wit and it will out at the casement; shut that and 'twill out at the key-hole; stop that, 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say 'Wit, whither wilt?'

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Nay, you might keep that cheque for it till you met your wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall never take her without her answer, unless you take her without her tongue. O, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband's occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool!

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Alas! dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I must attend the duke at dinner: by two o'clock I will be with thee again.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, go your ways, go your ways; I knew what you would prove: my friends told me as much, and I thought no less: that flattering tongue of yours won me: 'tis but one cast away, and so, come, death! Two o'clock is your hour?

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Ay, sweet Rosalind.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot of your promise or come one minute behind your hour, I will think you the most pathetical break-promise and the most hollow lover and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind that may be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful: therefore beware my censure and keep your promise.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind: so adieu.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let Time try: adieu.
Exit ORLANDO

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate: we must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head, and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love! But it cannot be sounded: my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the bay of Portugal.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Or rather, bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceived of spleen and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses every one's eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love. I'll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando: I'll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: And I'll sleep.
Exeunt
